A sequel is soon to be released...Yeah, baby!
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: A Master Class in Comic Timing, it's a Sweet, Sensational Satire
Review_body: Even today, fifteen years after its launch timer reached zero, Mike Myers's first romp as the gregarious gentleman spy with a heinous grill is mercilessly funny, shockingly well-written and every bit as entertaining as it was on day one. It's impressive enough for a film of this age to still retain so much of its initial charm, but to do so with the added weight of two derivative sequels, aping the original's best jokes at every turn, is borderline miraculous. Myers is at his rapid-fire best throughout this picture, setting up punchlines like dramatic authors might dangle plot threads, while somehow keeping the simple, delightful, central storyline in sight at all times. A biting satire of 60's culture and, naturally, the James Bond flicks that primarily celebrated it, there's no shortage of ammunition for the SNL alum's comic WMDs, but amidst so many presses of that red button there's also a sweet, tangible thought at its core. Clever, side-splitting comedy that might just stay fresh for decades to come.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: What a great premise: 1960s hero and arch villain both frozen, then unfrozen after thirty years to resume their global fight for power. A satire of the James Bond series, "Austin Powers ..." (played by Mike Myers) is a real disappointment. I laughed a couple of times. Otherwise, I endured the crude gags, stilted gimmicks, and the repellent character of Powers, with that grimaced smile and those ugly teeth.The problem here is the writing. The script just isn't funny. The humor is all forced. And there's a lot of missed opportunities. For example, Austin opens up a laptop, a device that wasn't available in the 1960s. Yet, he has no problem using it to chatter with Number Two (Robert Wagner). What an ideal setup for some laughs about changes in technology. But no; the script passes over this opportunity for some real comparisons to the 60s. Instead, we get way too much time spent on Porky's style bathroom "humor" that has nothing to do with cultural changes.The film is certainly colorful, as was the style for much of the latter half of the 1960s. Cinematography dazzles with flashy, glitzy, glittering visuals. But for what purpose? Probably the best element is the music. At least they brought back a couple of pop songs from the 60s. And the score is quite reminiscent of the earlier era.Casting is what it is. If you like Mike Myers, you'll no doubt like the film, since "Austin Powers ..." is basically a Mike Myers vehicle. Otherwise, the casting is largely irrelevant. Performances, beyond Myers' silliness, are neither good nor bad, since they're all exaggerated.I had hoped for humor that was more natural, more organic, and some clever comparisons to the 1960s. I got neither. This film is a blunt, in-your-face cinematic example of shallow, puerile, trashy insignificance that I suppose Mike Myers has become known for. Too bad.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: Cute film; could have been better
Review_body: Well. The spy genre spoof is pretty good. Elizabeth Hurley is such a babe, and a good actress to boot. She got right into the fun of the role. Way too much bathroom humor, though. I'm not a prude, but this was just too overdone in this film. I would like to think that Myers can come up with better jokes. Haven't seen TSWSM though, so we'll see if he did. The best parts were the hotel room scenes, where the naked actors were always strategically behind various objects, melons, cream pitchers, sausages, etc.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: One Freaked Out Groovy Happening, Baby. Yeah!
Review_body: Is it true this film bombed at the box office in 1997, and only achieved success when replayed on cable and home video? It had everyone laughing at the theater I saw this in. But it's not hard to imagine this film taking time to reach an audience, or latching on so well once it did."Austin Powers: International Man Of Mystery" or AP1, as I will refer to it, is a repellant, stupid, sky-high-on-itself little comedy that grows on you like a tumor, albeit a very benign one. Mike Myers wrote his own starring vehicle to demonstrate he still had a film career after milking the "Wayne's World" franchise dry. His Austin Powers is a lecherous British toad who lives a life of superspy danger, impossibly beautiful women, and appalling velvet fashion statements.He might have been funny for about 10 minutes, 15 tops, but what keeps the movie going are two other things. One is Michael Myers' other character, Dr. Evil, a bizarrely low-key megavillain who really can sustain comedy for long stretches at a time, belittling his henchmen and waving his cat around like a pointing stick. The other is the look and feel of this movie, a very detailed and vibrant homage to a certain type of 1960s look, call it Swinging London, that is very spot-on and disciplined even in its surreal goofiness. Notice there are wide-waled corduroys, ridiculous hats, miniskirts, but no paisley in evidence. Paisley would make it late-1960s flower-power rather than what it is, mid-1960s Mary Quant. It's not like you have to know any of this. It's just there, eye candy that serves the message of the film.And what is the message? Austin throws up a statement at the end which is supposed to sum it all up, that freedom and responsibility together are a groovy thing and so on, but for me the purpose of this film is twofold. One is to make you laugh, which it does. Not all the time. The bathroom bits are overdone to be sure, and Myers' idea of comic genius at times is to beat a joke into the ground and then stomp on it a bit more for good measure. But the film is funny, in part because Myers is no snob about making you laugh. He sees something funny, he goes for it. He's one present-day comic not afraid of shtick.The other purpose is a homage to the spy movie, specifically the Sean Connery James Bond movies; Bond imitators Matt Helm (Dean Martin), Harry Palmer (Michael Caine), and Derek Flint (James Coburn); and the over-the-top 1960s Bond farce "Casino Royale," which was the cinematic equivalent of the Hindenburg but remains a film everyone should see once. Peter Sellers in that last film is clearly a model for Austin: There's even a scene where Austin strikes poses on a revolving bed much like Sellers did in a 'Casino' scene with Ursula Andress. Myers said one of the 'Flint' movies was his favorite growing up, and clearly he is having nostalgic fun sending it all up. Bad cinema is impervious to satire, but these films weren't bad, and the kind of satire doled out in AP1 is never less than affectionate.Great opening credit sequence especially. I love the scene where Michael York plays the circa-1960s Basil Exposition; he looks like Brian Jones. This was followed by one sequel that was a little funnier though less focused and soulful, and then another several cuts below in quality, but this remains the definite Austin Powers film.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: From director Jay Roach, "Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery" is tongue-in-cheek fun that relies heavily on Mike Myer's comic genius as first the unlikely spy hero Austin Powers, and then the dastardly Dr. Evil (my favourite character in the film).The rest of the support cast, including the formidable Michael York and Robert Wagner, and the beautiful Mimi Rogers and Elizabeth Hurley, are cannon-fodder for Myers sizable talent - he wrote the movie as well.Some material doesn't work, but most of it is smashin'. Yeah baby, yeah!Saturday, July 10, 1999 - Video
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: The best and least crude of the three movies....kind of a classic!!
Review_body: Mike Meyers, Elizibeth Hurley, Michael York, Robert Wagner, Seth Green, Mindy Sterling, Paul Dillon, Mimi Rogers, Will Ferrell, Fabiana Udenio, Charles Napier, Carrie Fisher and Tom Arnold.This, as everyone knows, is about a 60's sex symbol(Mike Meyers) named Austin Powers. He is cryogenically frozen so that someday, when he is needed, he can foil his arch enemy Doctor Evil(Meyers also) who froze himself. Not only does this mark Meyer's first(and probably only) truly funny film, but it also marks one of Ferrell's earliest films. He plays Mustafa, which isn't a large role, but it's a funny one. Elizibeth Hurley plays Vanessa Kensington, Austin's new partner in spying and Mimi Rogers plays her mother. This, in my opinion, is a career starter for several people, and you should see it. Tom Arnold and Carrie Fisher have funny cameos.my rating-B PG-13 for sexual dialogue and content, some language, some mild drug content, some campy violence and some brief crude humor.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: This was the film that put two actors in the top ten. Mike Myers was a familiar face from his SNL days. After Austin Powers, Myers would become a comic genius over night. Elizabeth Hurley had been around, like Myers, for years in movies in both America and abroad. It wasn't til her sexy British charm in Austin Powers that opened several doors and opportunity. This was a crazy film none-the-less, besides 90 minutes of laughter and some surprise performances, all Austin Powers did was make a film you can laugh at. And what a film, the story alone makes you question reality. Somewhat of a "black" comedy, its more no holds bar comedy that stretches the bar of good taste and how much you can make a person laugh.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: A slow take-off out of the blocks for Austin Powers
Review_body: One has to realize that this film was pretty much a total failure. Sure, the film three times its budget, but one cannot look past the stale nature of the jokes and all of the inside jokes that only a few people could get (aptly known as the Dennis Miller ration). I commend Mike Myers for creating Austin Powers and giving my generation a great spoof character, but most of this film was quite a miss. Seth Green was great in his performance as the angry Scott Evil, and Mimi Rogers managed to look ravishing in her short role as Mrs. Kensington. Beyond that however, this film needed a little more work before it should have been released. 4/10
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: The first of the Austin Powers trilogy and definitely the best. Unfortunately these movies have aged horribly so that's not saying a ton. Still, when it came out this was hilarious and highly quotable. Some of it still warrants a chuckle but this is best off left as a memory.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body:
I have to say that I think Goldmember is the best of the Austin Powers trilogy, it's more refined and polished and the jokes have been tamed and finessed. However there would be no Goldmember without this one first having been released and a success.
I remember the first time I saw it and how I was hooked after just a few minutes by the fantastic opening sequence to The Soul Bossa Nova! I laughed hysterically all the way through back then and still laugh out loud today.
I love the silly jokes, the cameos (Christian Slater is genius in his role) and the fantastically funny and obscure mind of the writer, producer and lead, Mr Myers. When he plays a part, he really goes all out and he manages to do a great job playing two parts in this film.
The supporting cast is fantastic and although I would normally discuss how gorgeous Rob Lowe was (Which he obviously was and still is), I have to say there is a special place in my heart for both Miss and Mrs Kensington in those cat suits. I also love Basil, it's quite a small part for Mr York, but I love his typically British essence which works so well for a James Bond spoof, far superior to David Niven's effort, although I love him too!Brilliant writing, story, characters, actors, cutaways and good fun innuendo for all. This one however seems to have dated a bit more than Goldmember, but it won't stop me enjoying it as I was there at that time. I am still desperately waiting for a fourth instalment though.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body:
Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is a good and self aware spoof movie that doesn't always work but is fun when it does. Mike Myers is great as Dr Evil but only good as Austin Powers as he can be annoying at times. Elizabeth Hurley and Seth Green are really good. The amount of jokes that land just about outweighs the ones that don't. Jay Roach's direction is good and it's well paced.
The soundtrack is also really good.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Alright, I won't say I hated this movie. In fact I liked it a bit more then I expected. But I DO think it was severely over-hyped. Here is why I didn't like it much:Obvously-this movie isn't supposed to be taken seriously AT ALL. It's a comedy. But the trouble is, I just didn't find it that funny. Maybe this just isn't my brand of humor. I like comedies as a genre-for instance Something about Mary is a great one. It is vulgar at times yet manages to be funny ALL the time! With Austin Powers, it just doesn't work. Or maybe it does-for about the first 30 minutes-after that, it just becomes overdone and overplayed. And somewhat obnoxious. But then again, there are some people who hate Something about Mary so who knows-everyone has their favorites...I think the acting was wonderful-but Austin Powers is the type of movie, I think, one will either adore or just not like at all. It's not a 1 or 2 for me, which I thought it would be but it Also didn't get above the average mark for me and I wouldn't see it again.I'd say this is watchable but a bit tedious after awhile and sometimes obnoxious without lacking the true hilarity necessary in an obnoxious comedy to make it great(though I did appreciate the ending.)But overall, this never really made me laugh that much nor did it leave a lasting impression on me. Another thing- I have not seen the sequels except for the first few minutes of number 2 which throughly ruined any enjoyment I got from this one anyway so I doubt I'll be watching any more Austin Powers sequels. I'd rate this a 5 at best.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Mike Myers offers a comic turn on the over-hyped coolness of the 1960's against the equally clichéd spy-versus-master-criminal theme of 007 - also very much a product of the same decade.It's full of bright psychedelic colours and groovy fashions of the genre. For those who are too young to know; people did actually dress like him for a while. The sexual and sexist jokes are all par for the course and though politically-incorrect are still a great deal of fun.Myers plays both the hero and the villain - Dr Evil, and does each with a spoofy panache. All of the other characters do their adequate bit, including the seemingly ageless Robert Wagner.It's just a fun movie, but I have to say that I think it could have been a whole lot wittier with two such subjects to lampoon. Time and again I was expecting a far more comical result than the one I actually got.It maybe the 1960's just can't be spoofed. Like the saying goes; 'if you weren't there, you're square' and Mr Myers clearly wasn't. I think the decade was so iconic that it was its own self-parody. Check out 'Bedazzled' with Cooke and Moore and 'The Italian Job' with Micheal Caine. Both knock this into a cocked-hat.Still; it's worth a watch - I especially enjoyed the 'spontaneous' Dancing-In-The-Street sequence at the beginning, a hint at Martha Reese and The Mammas & The Pappas, both of whom made the song a 60's hit.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: In the 90s, Mike Myers was at the top of his game. He had a successful run on SNL and brought one of his most popular personas to the big screen in the ever-awesome WAYNE'S WORLD movies. In 1997, created an original character that was so popular it spawned it's own franchise: Austin Powers. The film is a spoof of the 60's spy genre and draws most of it's jokes by ripping on the James Bond series and it's quirks. Austin is a swinging bachelor in 1967, famed fashion photographer by day and daring secret agent by night. His arch-nemesis is Dr. Evil, a madman and total square who's bent on world domination. With Austin Powers constantly foiling his evil plans, Dr. Evil cryogenically freezes himself and launches into space to return in a future where Austin is no longer around to stop him. In 1997, Dr. Evil returns with plans to hold the world hostage with a subterranean nuclear missile. Austin, having anticipated Evil's return, had himself frozen and is thawed in '97 to battle his rival with the help of the beautiful Agent Kensington. That is, if he can adjust to life in a new era...This movie is hilarious and, if you're a fan of the 007 films, there's plenty of homages to keep you chuckling. A hidden underground layer, slow-moving easily-escapable traps, elaborate plans of world destruction, and a Swedish-made enlarger pump. Wait, how'd that get in there? It's got all the best elements of a spy film exaggerated to epic proportions with a colorful cast of characters. Evil has the expected menagerie of evil associates: head of his legitimate business front Number Two, founder of the militant wing of the Salvation Army Frau Farbissina, Korean ex-wrestler Random Task, and the voluptuous seductress Alotta Fagina. The first film is a goofy 90 minutes of quasi-vulgarity and slapstick, but it's got some decent heart in there as Austin is hit with the realization that his swinging, free-loving, chauvinist style doesn't fly as well in the 90's. Thirty years have passed and Dr. Evil's lameness is practically the norm. Austin confronts the concept of personal responsibility and finds love in Vanessa Kensington, the beautiful daughter of his partner from the 60s.I used to love Mike Myers. He was great on SNL and I loved both the WAYNE'S WORLD and AUSTIN POWERS series. He hasn't quite seen the same success in the new millennium (with the exception of the SHREK franchise) but this movie came at his strong point and his mojo-oozing secret agent is just getting started here. Myers pulls a double role, also performing as Dr. Evil and doing a spot on impression of Ernst Stavro Blofeld from the 007 movies. Elizabeth Hurley is gorgeous as Vanessa and a perfect foil for Austin's libidinous obsessions. Rounding out the cast are Robert Wagner, Seth Green, Michael York, and Will Ferrell in a bit part. There's a lot to enjoy here and I've seen the movie countless times over the years; it never gets old. The spastic humor and campy style pay homage to the most obvious well-known elements of the classic spy movies and leave the viewer (in my case, anyway) waiting for Austin "Danger" Powers' next adventure.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: The Satire wins out, but it's a close call.  Myers-as-Powers is incredibly repulsive in this movie (he's great as Dr. Evil).  There's a lot of spoofing going on here, and it's a lot more focused than, say, your average Hot Shots or Police Squad movie.  But a little bit of Myers goes a long, long, long way.  The movie also runs out of steam a bit, so near the end we're reduced to watching Powers endlessly try to move his go-cart.  The Dr. Evil scenes are hilarious though, and clearly the best part of the movie.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Mike Myers (Austin Powers) hits the mark with his own brand of comedy genius in the first of the Austin Powers movies. A 60's hipster is frozen in time for 30 years, to be brought back in the 90's to face his arch nemesis Dr. Evil (Also played by Mike Myers) With the gorgeous Miss Kensington (Elizabeth Hurley) by his side, he embarks on a madcap mission to foil Dr. Evils plans of world domination and it is a hilarious ride.Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery parody's the spy genre (Mainly the Bond Movies) spectacularly well. Littered with cameo's from the likes of Mimi Rogers, Robert Wagner and Burt Bacharach, this movie entertains with every gag and is quite simply 'GROOVY BABY!' - Sorry i couldn't resist lol8/10
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: (Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon.)This is a James Bond spoof aimed at retro nerds so that we might find an identification in our deprived lives. Hey, in this movie we get to cozy up--in your dreams, retard!-- to Elizabeth (drooling all over myself) Hurley. The flick sparkles (if that's the right word) with lame-o jokes and semi-sophisticated satire.Mike Myers wrote the script and stars as both Austin, the man of mystery (right, like the toe jam smell at the bottom of your closet is a mystery), and the cartoon villain Dr. Evil, who might be Dr. No cleaning his teeth with his pinkie. Speaking of teeth, he has the better teeth of our disjointed duo, speaking of which, notice that Hurley (would that Emma Peel had anything like her figure, but she too was English) doesn't actually soul kiss Austin. I mean, there are not only LIMITS, but contract clauses. I think Hurley was afraid that if she actually swapped tongues with him she would catch some horrid fungus amongus and THAT wouldn't be good for her career. However, check this out: for her next Austin Powers opus, "The Spy Who Shagged Me" she got $3-million up front.Look at it this way: if she could make flirty-flirty eyes with Rancid Teeth Man, she could conceivably, in your wildest dreams find YOU attractive, at least as the last man on earth. You and Elizabeth Hurley as the last two humans on earth! Eat your heart out, Sean Connery. Heck, all he had in Dr. No (1962) was Ursula Andress. (Come to recall: yummie, yum, yum.) And you too, Roger Moore. "Bond, James Bond," yourself.Myers makes himself as disgustingly nerdish as possible, but still the chicks swoon. There's some right-on satire here about the mystery of feminine desire. What DOES a woman want? The nerds never know but James Bond, Harrison Ford and (gulp) Mike Myers don't have to ask.All right, there is a plot to this Batman-like take off on the sixties become the nineties 007 spy diversion. But it's so familiar that I won't bother with it here. Some of the characters are interesting. There's Alotta Fagina played by Fabiana Udenio recalling Octopu**y and Pu**y Galore. (Well, she's not interesting, but her name is.) And think about this: Robert Wagner with the eye patch who was once a sophisticated ladies man--for example, The Pink Panther (1964)--is now a bloated old man having to wear extra large suit coats to hide his pot belly and sagging flesh. Now THAT evens the score for the old nerds who never got the girl, who, by the way, will like this as much as pimple-popping sixteen year olds.Myers knows what he's doing. There's a deep psychological seduction underneath the sixties garb and the nineties toilet humor that makes this strangely satisfying. For my part however I could only bear to watch it all the way to the very, very end in the hope that (PG-13 rating aside) that Hurley would disrobe a little and I could get a glimpse of that exquisite bod. But they teased me, especially in the matrimonial bed scene with the pineapples and the melons and the spice rack--whatta rack! Ha, ha, ha, ha.Remember as you watch this: it is not as bad as it looks. In fact, once you understand what Mike Myers is doing to your psyche, you might want to see it again.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: He's the sexiest, swingingest secret agent ever to combat evil - DOCTOR Evil, that is.... mwohahaha ha ha ha....He's Austin Powers, arguably Mike Myers's greatest, most memorable, most embraced, most quoted icon - in the film that made it all shagadelic, baby. AUSTIN POWERS: INTERNATIONAL MAN OF MYSTERY is a hip skewering of the spy movie genre, taking especial aim at James Bond. The more you know James, the more you'll love Austin.Myers is Austin Powers: superspy, posh Brit accent, smashing fashion sense, a Byrds wig, unruly teeth, and a gigantic male... symbol draped around his neck. We meet him dancing in the streets of 1960s swinging London, and I think he's doing The Froog.Austin Powers's nemesis is Doctor Evil (also played by Myers), a marriage of Donald Pleasance's Blofeld (from YOU ONLY LIVE TWICE) and apparently, as Myers confesses, Lorne Michaels (his producer on Saturday NIGHT LIVE). Myers whipcracks it out of the park with Dr. Evil, for as everyone knows, a hero is nothing without the villain who loves to hate him. And Myers immortalizes his hero and villain by imbuing them both with equal amounts of thunderball mojo.In the opening 1960s sequence, Dr. Evil escapes Powers by cryogenically freezing himself in an orbital rocket. So Powers volunteers to freeze himself as well, to combat Dr. Evil should he ever return to Earth. In the 1990s, Dr. Evil returns, sets up his underground lair in Nevada and tries to blackmail the world governments for "one MILLion DOLLars!" at which point his Number Two (Robert Wagner, brilliantly playing it straight) advises him that one million dollars isn't much these days. When he changes his ransom to "one HUNdred BILLion DOLLars," we start to twig to this movie's hook. It is part spy spoof, part fish-out-of-water, all Swedish-made penis enlarger.Meanwhile, Powers (unfrozen after 30 years, as the only man able to combat Dr. Evil) is having his own revelations - that the 90s are not as promiscuous as the 60s he left behind, and the slinky flirtations he engaged in with his previous spy partner, Mrs. Kensington (tightly leathered Mimi Rogers) are wasted on his current salubrious spy hard, Mrs. Kensington's daughter, Vanessa (achingly beautiful Elizabeth Hurley), a 90s woman, i.e. repressed and uptight about her sexuality. Which might explain Hugh's wayward thrust with that skank. (As Bill Maher has noted, "The most beautiful woman in the world – somebody's sick of f-king her!") The innocence of both hero and villain in a world that has left them behind is this movie's greatest hook. Snappily written by Myers and directed by Jay Roach like a man, man.Mindy Sterling is Dr. Evil's loudmouth secretary, Will Ferrell is a skin-darkened evil henchman, Michael York gamely plays Austin's boss, Basil Exposition, Fabiana Udenio is evil siren, Alotta Fagina (Pussy Galore, anyone?), and Seth Green perfectly captures X-Gen angst as Scott Evil, Dr. Evil's estranged son, whose pragmatic solutions to Dr. Evil's "Bond Villain" snares are a constant source of vexation for Dr. Evil.Does that make you HORNY, baby, yeah?
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Mike Myers,in interviews when asked about the genesis of the Austin Powers,said that it was inspired at least in part to the sort of Avengers/JAmes Bond movies that were a favorite of his father's,for whom he was was very close to. Judging by the enthusiasm and walloping energy he infused into writing,producing and(of course)acting in the films,I'd say that there is definitely a lot of love and personal investment in it.Myers plays both the title character and his arch-nemesis,Dr.Evil,as they are both products of the deep Cold WAr 1960s and the swanky,kitchy era that framed it. Both have been deep-frozen,and when Dr.Evil is unthawed in 1997,British Intelligence goes and unthaws POwers,who is sent to(big surprise)thwart Dr. Evil's plans. Along for the mission is Powers' one-time affiliate's daughter,the fetching Vanessa Kenzington(Elizabeth Hurley,never better fit for a film than here). Meanwhile,Dr.Evil(Ernst Blofeld look and all)has personal revelations of his own:namely,a genetically produced offspring that is an angry,back-talking son named Scott(Seth Green,full-froth). An ensuance of sight gags,pratfalls,an attempt at seduction(simultaneously done by Powers and an Italian vixen/spy(FAbiana Udenio),a romantic interlude(fostered along by Mr.Burt Bacharach!)in LAs Vegas,and a showdown in Evil's mountain lair all come into play before the film's fitful conclusion.Directed with transparency by JAy Roach,Myers ups the ante from his Wayne's World movies by giving these films as retro and kitchy as possible,replete with musical numbers,full-on Birtish slang and a cheekiness factor of ten! I--like many people--saw this film first on video,and it was a film that,FYI,was actually much more successfully in second release for home vid than it was in theatrical first release. Somewhat ironic,since the ensuing Austin POwers equals were probably,in my opinion,descending(though not bad any a one,really)in quality,yet did considerably better each in box office. No matter,it's quite the comedic gas,full of good clean naughtiness! Behave,indeed.

Review title: One of Mike Myers' best creations.
Review_body: Until last years dreadful Love Guru, Mike Myers used to be a genius. His first comedy, I think was So I married an ax murderer. To me, I think that was probably his best film. His next big hits were Waynes World and Waynes World 2. Which, I loved both of those. A few years after Wayne's World, Myers came up with one of the most memorable characters ever. Austin Powers was a success with critics but not quite at the box office. But after the first one, the series got more and more successful. Austin Powers: International man of mystery is the first film in the series. And by far the best. Austin Powers: International Man of mystery is so stupid that it's funny. In case you don't know, Austin Powers, the entire trilogy, is making fun of James Bond. If you've seen some of the Bond films, then you will know. For instance, instead of Pussy Galore, there's a character named Alotta Vagina. I won't spoil anymore of Austin Powers's fun. If you haven't seen Austin Powers, you should wake up and smell the roses. Austin Powers: International Man of mystery is hilarious. It's obvious that you should see it. It's a classic.The Plot: A spy named Austin Powers decided to freeze himself in 1967 so then he could defeat his life long nemesis Dr. Evil in the future. Dr. Evil also froze himself. So thirty years later, both Austin and Dr. Evil are unfrozen. Austin teams up with Vanessa Kensington, who's mother was his old partner and together, Austin and Vanessa try to stop Dr. Evil.

Review title: A baffling mixed bag that only works sometimes.
Review_body: When I originally saw Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery back in the 90s, I remember thinking it was mildly funny but it wasn't hilarious enough that I rushed out to buy a copy. Watching it now I found it more odd and puzzling than anything else. It really baffles me how they made this choice to blend a clear James Bond parody with a parody of a Beatles movie. Why the meshing of those two styles made sense to anyone is beyond me. Because I'm an avid fan of the James Bond franchise, what works for me in this film is everything to do with Dr. Evil. His personality is silly, and his henchmen are all humorous. I even love how Seth Green comes in as the voice of reason saying the things that so many of us have thought about Bond villains for decades. There are moments where they push the character of Dr. Evil a bit too far, and it loses some of the humor. But because I have a lot of knowledge about what he is spoofing, it doesn't bother me all that much.What doesn't work for me in Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is everything else. Austin Powers himself is a horribly annoying character in every way. I don't want to root for this idiot, I want to judo-chop him in the face. It feels like the film is trying to turn his outdated views on sex into a joke, but then rewards him with unprotected sex with multiple partners, so any humor is lost. Of course, the mere idea of women finding him sexy is a bit ridiculous as well, but we won't go there. The strange interstitial music breaks are pointless, and really drive home that 60s Beatles vibe. Finally, the two LONG scenes of naked characters covering their private parts with conveniently placed items lose any humor after about 5 seconds, even though they seem to drag on for more than 5 minutes. That is actually the biggest weakness of the humor in this film...not knowing when to stop a joke. If I could just have a Dr. Evil movie, then I'd be a happy camper, but since this is titled Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery, I don't feel much need to revisit it again.

Review_body: Austin Powers is a groovy little movie. Telling of Austin Powers, a secret agent from the 1960's, he his awaken from cryofreeze in 1997 when his arch nemesis, Dr. Evil returns to Earth and plans a new diabolical plan. Now, Austin must stop his foe from drilling a nuclear warhead into the Earth's core, but first, he needs to get used to how society in the 1990's behaves.This comedy is a raunchy spoof of the James Bond films, this movie pokes fun at the typical formula of Bond films. Mike Myers does a good job playing both Austin Powers and Dr. Evil. Seth Green plays Scott Evil, the cloned son of Dr. Evil, who also contributes to the humor as he points out how flawed Dr. Evil's traps and ideas are. The movie has a good story, the cast is amazing, and the jokes are funny and creative for a PG-13 films

Review_body: It's 1967 and famous British spy Austin Powers has defeated his nemesis Dr. Evil. Dr. Evil proceeds to do the only logical thing, escape in a rocket ship disguised as a Big Boy statue and cryogenically freeze himself (and his cat). Austin Powers volunteers to be frozen in case Dr. Evil returns to wreak havoc in the future. Thirty years pass. It's 1997 and Dr. Evil is back. Time to unfreeze Austin Powers who is about to find out the '90s aren't quite as groovy as the '60s.Dr. Evil plots to steal a nuclear weapon and hold the world hostage for one million dollars! Er, one hundred billion dollars! A million bucks just doesn't buy what it used to. Dr. Evil has got a lot to catch up on, as does Austin Powers, the product of the swinging '60s who is very much out of place in the more sedate '90s. This leads to some good laughs, many of which center around Austin's attempt to get his new partner, the stunningly beautiful Vanessa Kensington, to sleep with him. Sadly, Austin's tried-and-true '60s seduction techniques aren't going to work on Vanessa. Meanwhile, there's the small matter of foiling Dr. Evil's dastardly plan.The movie maybe never hits the heights of comedic genius. It's never uproariously funny but it is reasonably amusing. And charming too. Mike Myers does very well with the dual roles of Austin Powers and Dr. Evil though there is the nagging sense that the bad guy is funnier than the titular hero. There is little question the funniest moments come from Dr. Evil, the prototypical James Bond villain who knows he's the prototypical James Bond villain. Among other things this means he must have over-elaborate ways of doing everything when he knows darned well a simpler way would surely suffice. And it also of course means he is fated to be frustrated. What's a guy got to do to get some sharks with frickin' laser beams attached to their heads? Dr. Evil is a hoot, Austin Powers sometimes less so but you root for him. He's charming in his own very unique way. Maybe Vanessa will even come to love him. Happily Elizabeth Hurley, playing Vanessa, proves to be a model who can actually act. She more than holds her own with Myers, the two work well together. There are other familiar faces in the cast, including Michael York, Robert Wagner and Seth Green, who all do well with their respective roles. But the movie obviously belongs to Myers, this is his baby. And he pulls it off well enough. Yes, the humor is hit and miss but there are enough hits to keep you smiling. This is the spoof James Bond deserved. Yeah, baby, yeah!
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: Actually funny, unlike certain other James Bond spoofs
Review_body: I was eleven years old around the time this hit comedy came into stores, so I was perhaps a little too young to see it. When I was sixteen, all three of the Austin Powers movies were out in stores, and I finally watched them all in reverse order. I have now seen each of them several times, and recently watched this one, the original "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery", for the first time in a couple years (back when I last watched the entire trilogy). It was my first time seeing it after watching all the James Bond movies in order, so I now understand some of the parodies, and I think my latest viewing of this 1997 comedy was a lot like the one before it. I may not like it as much as I did as a teenager, but I still laughed, you can be sure about that. It's definitely more watchable than the 1967 version of "Casino Royale", and probably certain other lacklustre Bond spoofs as well.In 1967, Austin Powers is a British secret agent and a stereotypical 60's womanizer. His archenemy is Dr. Evil, a man with plans for world domination! One night, while the agent chases after his foe, the evil doctor manages to get away in a rocket, where he cryogenically freezes himself, and plans to return sometime in the future! Powers is then cryogenically frozen so he will be available to continue his battles against the madman whenever he happens to come back. Dr. Evil finally returns from suspended animation thirty years later, in 1997, and immediately reunites with his colleagues to figure out new ways to try and take over the world! So, Powers is unfrozen and sent with Vanessa Kensington, the daughter of a woman he worked with in the 60's, to once again try and foil his archenemy's plans. Unfortunately for Powers, a lot has changed in thirty years, and his womanizing ways will no longer be tolerated.Comedian Mike Myers, who wrote the story, plays two characters in the film, Austin Powers and Dr. Evil. He does a good job with both, playing a likable, charming fool and goofy parody of James Bond villain Ernst Stavro Blofeld. Both of these characters can still make me laugh with their antics. The washroom stall gag, Powers mistaking the mother of his boss, Basil Exposition, for a man in disguise, and the conflict between Dr. Evil and his son, Scott, are three things I can point out as comic highlights, but those aren't the only ones. Certain other characters can be quite funny as well, such as Frau Farbissina, a villain played by Mindy Sterling, with her screech, and Mustafa, Dr. Evil's henchman played by Will Ferrell, even though this chararacter isn't in the film for long. Yes, this is a raunchy comedy, with sex, nudity, and some language, which I don't have a problem with, as long as it's funny, but if this type of dirty humour bothers you, and/or you don't care for Mike Myers as a comedian, then "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" is not for you. However, if you like Myers' sense of humour and want to laugh, this James Bond spoof could be your kind of comedy.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: My Take: Definitely one of the funniest spy movie spoof ever.One is a the hottest spy of the 60's. Even with bad teeth, he has a way with the women (in the 60's that is). The other one is a megalomaniac, reminiscence of James Bond's mortal enemy Ernst Blofeld. All he wants is to rule the world, and is the worst enemy of that super-spy. That spy your sure to love is Austin Powers, and that megalomaniac is the "sinister" Dr. Evil, and both are played by Mike Myers, and when they were frozen in the 60's and reawakened during the 90's, their fish-out-of-water.All this and so much more are in AUSTIN POWERS: INTERNATIONAL MAN OF MYSTERY, an immensely enjoyable and funny spoof of the classic James Bond movies, an idea that proved to be some failure in 1967's CASINO ROYALE parody. Although not every joke in this movie will make you laugh like a fool, all the jokes are right on timing, as they are quite relevant. And the film's biggest long-running joke, wherein two 60's inhabitants try to blend in to the much-changed 90's atmosphere, is slick and cleverly idealistic.The plot in a nutshell concerns Austin Powers and Dr. Evil (both played by Myers) confronting each other once again in the 90's. Evil's plan is to gain profit from world leaders and, after a number of bad and dated ideas (Framing Prince Charles to divorce and putting a hole in the atmosphere which all supposedly happened), he finally comes up with a plan to use a warhead to terrorize the world for 100 billion dollars. Elizabeth Hurley co-stars as Vanessa, Austin's fellow agent not attracted by Austin's approach to sex ("Do I make you horny, baby?", Michael York also co-stars as Basil Exposition, Austin's boss and Robert Wagner as Number 2, Dr. Evil's "cycloptic" colleague (he wears an eye-patch).There are a few uneven jokes that fall short of the point, but majority are really great jokes, like ones that exceed upon the PG-13 rating it was limited to. Myers is a natural, carrying two roles in one film, making them both very hilarious and interesting. Director Jay Roach is very energetic and fun-loving in his work. The script, co-written by Myers, is filled with jokes we thought will never work. Turns out they will, if given to the right hands.A very funny comedy, surprisingly holds up very memorably.Rating: **** out of 5.

Review title: An Antidote For A Rainy Day
Review_body: I'm not a Mike Myers fan, and I avoided this film--and its sequels--like the plague when they were on the big screen. But I now know the error of my ways: AUSTIN POWERS is one of the freshest bits of purely entertaining, mindless fluff to come along in quite a while, the perfect antidote to an overcast and bad-mood sort of day.The story is an amalgamation of the more excessive plot ideas of such films as DIAMONDS ARE FOREVER and OUR MAN FLINT. Fashion photographer by day and swinging spy by night, Austin Powers is the toast of psychedelic London--and more than a match for Dr. Evil. But when Dr. Evil has himself frozen, Powers does the same, and the two defrost some thirty years later and resume their battle in the much more up-tight 1990s. The most obvious target of the spoof is the James Bond films, but fans of 1960s film will have a field day spotting the film's take offs on such characters as Matt Helm, Derek Flint, Emma Peel, celebrities like The Beatles and Andy Warhol, and such diverse films as THE TENTH VICTIM and the camp classic DR. GOLDFOOT AND THE GIRL BOMB. And dare we mention the sixties' own classic swinging spy spoof, the infamous CASINO ROYALE? Myers is greatly amusing in the double role of Austin Powers and Dr. Evil, both of whom have considerable difficulty adjusting to everything from safe sex to inflation, and Elizabeth Hurley is quite good in the Diana Rigg-ish role of sidekick Vanessa Kensington. But the real fun here is in the details--and the details include every one from Michael York to Robert Wagner to Burt Bacharach to Carrie Fisher, "Fembots" with killer pasties, and Italian sexpot Fabiana Udenio as a character with the most devastating name since Honor Blackman hit the screen in GOLDFINGER. The soundtrack is just as swinging as it gets, with blasts of everything from "These Boots Are Made For Walking" and "I Touch Myself." And look for a hilarious spoof of Bob Fosse-inspired choreography during the main credits! You won't find any deep thoughts in AUSTIN POWERS, and thank heaven for it: giggles and grins are the order of the day, and the film delivers them in abundance. The DVD is a nice one as well, offering your choice of widescreen or pan-and-scan, some entertaining notes and deleted scenes, and amusing commentary. Buy it and keep on your shelf for that rainy day.Gary F. Taylor, aka GFT, Amazon Reviewer
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Mike Myers is quite the character, and I mean that literally. He's undoubtedly great at coming up with over the top and eccentric characters and Austin 'Danger' Powers is probably his most famous. Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is the first film in the Austin Powers series where Meyers stars as the suave British secret agent, as well as his nemesis, the pasty white Dr. Evil. The film opens in the 60's where promiscuous sex and drugs are the essence of popular culture and Powers is living it up, womanizing left and right as the sex symbol of all of Britain. But while Powers is foiling a plot of Dr. Evil's, Evil cryofreezes himself to escape. Powers has no other option but to cryofreeze himself so that he may be unfrozen if Dr. Evil ever decides to return. Thus we are thrown into present day, which in this case is the 90's, where Powers must foil Dr. Evil's plot to take over the world. Utter goofiness ensues, some of it completely idiotic, some of it completely hilarious.Austin Powers is a perfect poster child for parody films, and it does a hilariously great job at parodying the rampant sexual innuendos, overly cheesy plot lines, and stereotypically flat characters of 1960's spy films. Thus, the entire film is spent making fun of other films, thus any inconsistency, continuity error, or plot hole exists only to perpetuate the parody theme of the film. Thus, you can't judge Austin Powers on its plot, characters, or most things that you normally would judge a film for. You can really only judge it on its humor. The film has one goal and one goal only, to make the audience laugh. So basically if it makes you laugh it passes, if it doesn't it fails. In my case, I laughed so there... the film passes in my book.There's not much else to say. I'm not really the biggest fan of goofy humor, but I laughed out loud more than once during this film. And while it is mostly silly antics riddled with fart and poop jokes, there's a baseline of cleverness that runs through the film that makes it a lot of fun to watch. You can only enjoy this film for exactly what it is on the surface, and I most certainly did. It's just one of those comedies you will like or you won't, and I luckily did.

Review_body: I'm not quite sure why, but whenever I watch an Austin Powers film I'm always filled with a growing sense of disappointment. It's certainly not because of the two lead characters, who are destined to fuel many late night "who's the funniest?" drinking debates. I still can't make up my mind on that score. While the humour is occasionally near the knuckle (see the "Mama Cass" joke), it's usually affectionate, and Myer's cod English accent has me in stitches every time. I particularly love his use of antiquated Brit phrases ("Shut yer cakeole"; "on yer bike"), though if I wanted to be picky I'd point out no Englishman would ever say "carnies" or "popsicle". Dr.Evil is just as good, his description of his father - "made outrageous claims that he invented the question mark and had a penchant for buggery" - being particularly amusing.One of the ways in which this humour is successful is an almost "Carry On" style of audacity over cheese. So that Austin's answer to "how dare you break wind before me" being the ancient "I'm sorry baby, I didn't realise it was your turn" produces a laugh at the spirited lameness of it, rather than wincing. Lots of the jokes are like this, and though the "private parts covered by strategically placed inanimate objects" (one of the few things they did better in the sequel, using sillouettes) doesn't really work, most of them get by. The Bond gags are spot-on, too, and anyone citing them as unsophisticated is missing the point. Names like Basil Exposition, Patty O'Brien and Random Task are perfect mickey-takes, as well as Frau Farbissina's vocation as "founder of the militant wing of the Salvation Army". Evil's plan of "let's just do what we always do, hijack some nuclear weapons and hold the world hostage" ably illustrates the agenda.However, while all these gags are pretty funny in a lovably juvenile way, I always find that the laughter stops after the first half an hour. I initially thought that this was because the films couldn't maintain their momentum, and while this is partly true, it's not wholly the case. I happened to catch a bit of this at the usually lacking half-way point and laughed just as loudly as I normally do at the start. It turns out that while the two leads have a very funny joke each, it IS just a single joke, and no film can survive on such a paltry supply. The budget-heavy sequel saw Michael McCullers join Myers as a co-writer, and it wasn't nearly as good. While some of the setpieces were inspired - Dr.Evil on Jerry Springer and a Thomas Crown Affair spoof - generally it was a flat retread. Quite amusing when watched alone, seen in conjunction with International Man of Mystery it's a reheated rehash. A quick example is the innuendo names for the villainous girls. The first gave us Alotta Fagina, the sequel Ivana Humpalot. The first is clearly the funnier version of the same joke, something that's symptomatic of the whole movie. The first was a likeable, knockabout parody of culture clashes and the Bond franchise. The Spy Who Shagged Me is a parody of Austin Power's own cult. Many of the jokes are reused wholesale, including multiple puns about a dead guard, the prolonged laughing gag and Mustafa still being alive, though out of sight. The only new additions to the formula fail to work. The only reason to watch So I Married An Axe Murderer was Myer's joint role as a drunken Scotsman, so it's rather odd that here the Scots "Fat B*****d" falls singularly flat. Mini-Me, Dr.Evil's clone, is also too vicious-looking to really appeal. A smugness pervades the whole piece, and the product placement of a certain lager (which reportedly increased sales by 15%) is as inappropriate as the unnecessary plugs for AOL in both films.This film, and its sequel, do make me laugh. Just never as much as I'd like them to.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: Could Have Been Hilarious But Ended Up Weak Instead
Review_body: The movie was clearly meant to be a spoof of 1960's British culture and of James Bond movies. The beginning was energetic and promising. Unfortunately soon afterward the movie runs out of steam.The James Bond character in this movie was not like the well-dressed man of the Bond movies but rather a long-haired mod. Even then the concept could have worked. But there are too many "fish out of water" jokes and the others aren't really funny either. A long-haired cat becoming bald is hardly amusing. Nor are the other sexual or other gags very clever either.The sequels were supposed to be better, but I feel no compulsion to check them out. If you want good spy spoof comedy, I recommend watching old "Get Smart" episodes instead.

Review_body: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997, Dir. Jay Roach)Story Mike Myers plays Austin Powers. A sex-mad spy who worked in the 60's along with Mrs. Kensington. He freezes himself and later released in the late 90's. Times are very different for Austin, who still believes that the sex lifestyles of the 1960's are still alive and well. He is assigned along with Mrs. Kensington's daughter, Vanessa, and must work together to stop Dr. Evil, who is also played by Mike Myers. Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is a spy spoof which delivers many jokes and laughs and includes cameos from many including Carrie Fisher and Will Ferrell.Actors Let's start with the lead actor, Mike Myers. He being a Canadian born actor plays an English spy, and it's as convincing as it can be. His classic English accent is spot on and makes it seems as he has always been an English citizen. His costumes are amazing, and really stand out, especially in the scene where he is playing in a casino. Myers also plays the villain, Dr. Evil. You really have to study him, to see Myers behind the makeup. Although they are both played by the same actor, Austin Powers and Dr. Evil are two very different characters. All the other character are amazingly real, and although they mirror certain spy characters from other films, there are no direct copy of the character, such as Random Task. He is an obvious spoof of Odd Job from Goldfinger, but has a different personality than him. Elizabeth Hurley plays a wonderful 'Powers Girl' and the cameos are welcoming as they are not just cameos, but also fit in as part of the story. Will Ferrell is wonderful as Mustafa.Music The music in this film is very different to what you will find in modern films today. Like the films which are a parody of the old classic films, the soundtrack is identical to the type of music you find in a 60's film. George S. Clinton teams up with Burt Bacharach to bring a soundtrack very similar to the original Casino Royale spoof. Its theme is catchy and has become recognisable all over.Special Effects This is a film which is not particularly known for its special effects. There are some CGI (computer generate imagery) used, but this is very little. If you've seen many of the earlier James Bond films, you will understand how the special effects are used in this. There are many explosions during the confrontation, with stunt men bouncing over the rails. This is not bad though, and adds the feel of the film. The background used when Austin Powers is in the car are even similar to the early film. Watch an old film and you will notice how obvious the background image looks during shots inside are car. This is used here and can be hilarious to those who are aware of it.Conclusion Overall, 'Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery' is a hilarious film and different to a lot of movie spoofs we are encountering these days. It might not be for everyone, and you would find it a lot funnier if you have great knowledge of the spy genre, so you should brush up on your films if you're planning to watch this. As Austin would say, this film is simply shagtastic."Ooo, Behave!"  Austin Powers (Mike Myers)

Review title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is groovy, baby.
Review_body:
Mike Myers shines as the secret agent desperately needing dental work in this lighthearted spoof of things shagadelic. Austin was a swinging international spy for British intelligence (?) in the 1960s. He was cryogenically frozen along with his archenemy, Dr. Evil (also Myers). After 30 years, Powers is thawed, and he's in for a few '90s surprises. Stewardesses are now flight attendants. Carnaby Street is no longer the center of the world. Dancing has gone way beyond the Frug, the Jerk and the Monkey. Crushed velvet is a fashion "don't," and free love costs a lot.
A somewhat shell-shocked Austin quickly teams up with Vanessa (Elizabeth Hurley), the daughter of his former Mrs. Peel-like sidekick, Mrs. Kensington. Meanwhile, Dr. Evil is having problems at home. He has a test-tube slacker son, Scott Evil, who can't relate to Daddy's desire for world domination. Myers is a total delight no matter which part he's tour-de-forcing. Hurley appears game, but doesn't seem to possess a natural flair for comedy. Robert Wagner, Carrie Fisher, Mimi Rogers and Burt Bacharach make cameos. Sure, it sometimes stoops to third-grade witticisms, but much of Austin Powers is movie-wise funny. What was once Wayne's world is now Powers' planet.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Austin Powers is a movie that you can watch over and over and never get tired of the wicked stabs at the venerable spy genre.  Mike Myers is delightfuly over the top as Austin Powers and his arch nemesis, Dr. Evil. By keeping the film light, and never resting too long on any given scene, we move easily through the story, and we're introduced to a gallery of great supporting characters.  The best one being Scott Evil, who is having problems with the fact that he was artificially created in a laboratory.

Review_body: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery the first in the Austin Powers series, is a just about good film and make's for a comedy with all the trademarks you can expect from such a film. Quite funny and give's off some good laughs for you, but also provides a fairly good spy film as well just like a James Bond but with much funnier humour than even Roger Moore. I'll tell below why I think it is a good film.The story is solid and as I said a good spy film and with Dr Evil being one of the most famous and most funny villains in film, you can't help just feel good whilst watching it. The film has a slow start but get's into it quick enough and Powers is humorous throughout but it really is Dr Evil who steals the humour off him in this first instalment. Finally on the story it is actually a good Sci-Fi too which blends in well with the comedy and crime and also makes for some crazy sequences.I do like Mike Myers in this film but I felt he failed slightly at playing Austin Powers as his other portrayal of Dr Evil is much funnier and basically rules he comedy in this piece. Liz Hurley is a good performance as Power's agent helper and she guides the more serious side of agents which is then lampooned by Austin. Finally One great comedy part of this is with Dr Evil's table of evil people, and his son Scott who is just brilliant(Seth Green portraying) and the only person who isn't frightened of Dr Evil and constantly complains about little things.I think the set's and gadgets etc used are great because they optimise what James Bond uses but completely humour's them and makes for some funny joke set up's. It is well written comedy wise by Mike Myers who serve's as the main actor, producer and writer and he put's together a film that he truly owns, it also makes you want to see what he could write for the next instalments and that would test his skill that is seen in this film.The film can be unfunny and not that I think everyone will hate the jokes but some jokes just miss the mark and become just to crude, slightly less crude and this film could have been massively better but it is still a good comedy all around. I think also that the story is obviously not the strongest ever but what do you expect with a comedy, and don't think this film isn't funny because people say it isn't, just watch it first.I recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good and crude comedy that can be tasteless at times but manages enough class to be funny but also sophisticated in it's jokes. If you don't enjoy a lot of sexual humour then this isn't for you as Powers is a sex addicted man from the 60's who tries it on with any female he see's it seems but though it isn't serious perverseness he is obviously making himself look stupid to make you laugh.Overall a just about good film, it only just scrapes out being good rather than just fairly good but I think many will agree with me, although some will be disappointed with this film as well so I expect mixed reviews from most who see it. Worth a watch and if you watch it purely for the comedy you can enjoy yourself, just don't open your mind too much or you may not enjoy it as much.

Review title: Oh, the parsing of the mockery.
Review_body: Wildly inventive and accessible, Mike Myers creation of Austin Powers is both cunning satire and eternally sophomoric, and I loved it! The punning of the 60's is quick and inclusive, regardless of your stance on the social issues of the time, and the Bond/Foe bits play into the genre perfectly. Dr. Evil gets little credit for bringing the two together when he says to his son, "you just don't get it". If you feel the mike Myers character is infectious and continually out of place, then you'd have enjoyed this Bond send off. If not, then count the references, point out what is silly rather than inventive, talk about distance between the viewer and the object of ridicule and feel better about yourselves. That's what Austin would have wanted for you!

Review_body: Mike Myers is the chalk to your cheese, the salt to your sweet. He can improve a mix, or outright destroy it. He's exploited James Bond's core attributes, ruining the stereotypes and the clichés we've grown use to, and come up with not one, but two egotistical maniacs that allow him to rein free and pretty much do as he pleases. The humour falls in to the slapstick category, and sometimes it scrapes the bottom of the comedy gene pool. It's clearly not for everyone. For every comedy gold there's a rusty, wooden pun. Austin Powers (Myers) is an English secret agent from the 60's whose charm, wit and stupidity gets him along in life. His evil nemesis, the aptly named Dr. Evil (also Myers), freezes himself in space and reappears 30 years later in the 90's. Powers follows in pursuit to once and for all bring Dr. Evil down. This crazy plot works because both hero and villain are out of their depth after missing so much from the last 3 decades. Dr. Evil threatens to destroy the world unless he receives $1m from the United Nations, and Austin realises he cannot sow his seed like he use to, thanks to a strong willed, sexy Elizabeth Hurley. If you can't stomach International Man of Mystery's first 5 minutes, don't bother with the rest. If you're a die-hard Bond fan, stay clear; Myers has duplicated Blofeld to shocking effect.Check out my other reviews on http://straighttelling.co.uk
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Storywise its a fairly simple good vs bad affair but the characters and writing puts it above any other spy spoof made before or since

Review_body: A generally hit-and-miss effort with enough hits to be fun. Mike Myers stars as the title character, a groovy 1960s spy who, after decades of being cryogenically frozen, is unthawed in modern times to thwart his old nemesis, Dr. Evil (also played by Myers). Along the way, the film takes plenty of pokes at pop culture, both past and present, and features no shortage of sex jokes.But the best moments come when the film takes aim at spy movies, particularly the earlier entries in the James Bond series. One henchman, for instance, throws his shoe at people when a pistol would obviously be more practical. There's also a memorable moment when our hero is finally captured. Rather than simply shooting him, Dr. Evil places him in an elaborate device that slowly lowers him into a pool of hungry alligators. Of course Dr. Evil (the best character in the movie) has better things to do than ensure the plot goes according to plan, and Austin escapes certain death. Scenes like that help make the movie fun even when it isn't particularly funny."Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" was not a huge box office success, but it built up a solid reputation on video. That spurred two (to date) highly-successful sequels, which squeezed whatever was left of the concept - and then some. If you still haven't seen the original, it's worth a look. Despite its silliness, there is a decent comedy here.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Anyway, the movie contains lots of cool and silly lines that'll hook up in your mind for a long time. And check out those cameos!

Review title: What this movie (as well as its sequel) needs is a good cutting
Review_body: Being not a very bad movie it lacks decency badly. "Gaudy trash" are the best words to describe this fest of "hits and misses". The movie gets from vulgar and embarrassing to quite funny and cute. What this movie (as well as its sequel) needs is a good cutting. If you cut all the bad and vulgar things out of the film and leave everything genuinely funny, you can get a very bright example of modern comedy. Unfortunately it has more misses than hits. Therefore only 4 out of 10 and I am very sad that such a brilliant concept and such a bright film went many wrong ways and made too many wrong turns.I don't think that I should name all the misses, do I. Maybe just one or two, or three for you just to understand what I mean. Dr Evil's speech during a kind of "psychological father-son rehabilitation seminar" is not funny but vulgar. All the fuss with the "Swedish gadget" is very annoying. The ways the evil characters are killed off leaves much to be desired: they don't have a chance to show off (it looks as if the filmmakers were short of ideas). The evil female character disappears without any noticeable performance, and so on and so forth.If it were only 50 minutes long but with the best excerpts included, it would be a very well made comedy.Mr Michael Myers, if you read this, take note that you do have talent but there is great responsibility for every talented comedian to put it right. If you make a comedy, you should make it in such a way that every child and adult could enjoy it without getting embarrassed and annoyed. Adult sexual humour often kills even smartest comedies while the permanent classics of Mr Charles Chaplin, Mr Buster Keaton, and Mr Norman Wisdom will remain immortal Art of comedy genre. Did these masters ever get vulgar in their classics? You know the answer.4 out of 10 with a sigh. Thanks for attention.

Review_body: For those of us who are too young to have experienced most of the James Bond movies, we've had to look to other British spies to grow up with. The British spy of our generation is the brain child of Saturday Night Live alum Mike Myers in the form of Austin Powers, who makes his debut in this film, Internation Man of Mystery. While recycling jokes and characters from the James Bond movie, there is a certain freshness to the spy, as he is a 60s swinger trying to make it in the politically correct days of the late 90s. Powers is brought out of cryogenic freezing in 1997 to take on his arch-enemy, Dr. Evil (also played by Myers), who himself is returning to Earth after 30 years and has trouble adapting to the new world. The best jokes come from Powers and Dr. Evil trying to catch up on the time they've missed, trying to use today's technology, and adjust for inflation of the dollar. One million dollars does not go as far as it used to, much to Dr. Evil's surprise. The Bond references are funny too, but the part I like best about this movie is how characters had to adapt to 30 years of civilization change.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: I have friends who do impressions of Doctor Evil, and they always make me laugh. I've been known to stick my pinkie in the corner of my mouth and say "Laze-ur" myself, but I've never found the Austin Powers films even slightly funny. Doctor Evil sums this movie up perfectly when he tell his son Scott "You just don't get it, do you?" That's right Doc, I've no idea why I didn't go and bang my head against a wall rather than carry on watching "Austin Powers".I sat through this film stony-faced, cringing inwardly at the obvious sexual innuendos, crude jokes about bodily functions and the looks of discomfort on some well-respected actors' faces.Taking what is essentially a James Bond plot and tacking on a lot of gags has been done before, in the original "Casino Royale" and "Carry On Spying". Neither of those films made me laugh much either.I enjoyed the daft 60s musical number where Austin parades through a Hollywood version of Swinging London, but there's about an hour and a half of celluloid gackass tacked onto it that I'd rather forget about.

Review title: The mojo is strong in this one!
Review_body: The first of the Austin Powers movies is also the best. A delightful spoof of the James Bond films and similar spy movies, Austin Powers is a top agent of the British Secret Service in the late 1960s, and also a world renowned fashion photographer, swinger and sex icon. When his nemesis Dr. Evil freezes himself and is shot into space, Austin also freezes himself to fight him again should he return. Both of them are thawed out in 1997, picking up where they left off, but both considerably out of place coping with the strange new world of the late nineties, with many hilarious consequences. Free love and carefree experimenting with mind expanding drugs are out of the question for Austin despite working with gorgeous female agent Vanessa Kensington (Elizabeth Hurley), while Dr. Evil has a hard time wrapping his mind around the fact that one million dollars just isn't enough money to ask for ransom any more, plus he also has to deal with his son Scott Evil (Seth Green) who was artificially created in his absence. Overall, Austin is funny, but it's Dr. Evil who gets all the really good jokes: since Mike Myers performs both characters, he gets out on top of both. The movie failed at the box office though, but turned out a surprise hit in video stores to such an extent, it nevertheless spawned two sequels, both of them good for a decent laugh but not nearly as much as this one.

Review title: Best to watch when in a certain mood
Review_body: Personally, I like the Austin Powers movies. The only problem with them is that in order to get real laughs, you have to be in a silly mood. Most of the people who said this had no humor probably watched it when they weren't in that mood.There are several good things about this movie. Such as the way it spoofs 007, and other spy movies of the '60's. The beginning of this movie takes place during the '60's, but then it jumps ahead to the late '90's. This movie mixes the culture of the '60's into the '90's, and does it very well.There is a lot of sexual humor in this movie, but anyone who is in elementary school probably won't pick up on any of it.In many ways, this is just as good as the sequels, but in many ways I prefer the sequels. It probably has something to do with how the sequels have more characters, and in many ways better humor. This is worth watching, but only if you're tired or in a silly mood.

Review title: Groovy stuff, but this is Dr. Evil's shag machine, baby....
Review_body: Mike Myers undoubtedly has great comedic talent, but sometimes it wears thin, especially in the WAYNE'S WORLD movies.  This time, he takes on the swinging 60's mod scene, as well as early James Bond.  Everyone knows the basic gimmick, freezing the shag-hero until 1997 so he can take on the evil Dr. Evil (also Myers).  The world has changed: no free love, no more-mind freeing drugs.  Some people have talked about the picture as "slapstick" with a message.  The Austin Powers character must adapt to the drastic change and un-idealistic 90's.  The thing is, Austin Powers is not all that funny (except the rotting teeth and hilarious shagadelic dance). Dr. Evil is the one to watch.If you are not familiar with Mod, or any Bond movies, you may find yourself turning this flick off.  Most of the jokes are inside ones with these topics in mind.  However, the Dr. Evil character has you laughing all the way to the end.  It is truly funny seeing an arch-criminal going to family therapy with his son.  He tells the group his son is "quite astute", and not easliy killed.  Evil steals the movie by partaking in every cliche the spy genre is comprised of and his cat, Mr. Bigglesworth, is the most important thing to him besides world domination.There are some great sight gags, especially when Austin and the beautiful Elizabeth Hurley strut around naked.  With careful choreography, their privates are never exposed.  Again, while Powers shags on, baby, you have to say this is Dr. Evil's film.  No doubt he and Mr. Bigglesworth will be back for the sequel, and perhaps his son has started that evil petting zoo.

Review title: A pretty funny spoof of the spy genre
Review_body: "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" is a pretty funny spoof of the spy genre, especially making fun of the James Bond movies. I did thought this movie was hilariously funny, when I was young back then. Now by looking back at it, it was not as hilariously funny as I remember. Don't get me wrong I still think that this is a funny movie, but it wasn't as hilariously funny as I remember. When you have some dirty jokes in the movie like having our two lead actors getting naked, it just depends on whether is funny or not; at times it can be funny, and at times it can't. I just only wish if the jokes where funny if they would make me laugh the most. Nevertheless, the movie is still funny. Aside from the humor, some of the CG effects of the Big Boy weren't that good either, but it does not take me out of the movie as I am enjoying it. So those are the only parts where I have issues with, but they are not really a big deal. I thought Mike Myers has done a great job for not only writing the script, but playing two parts in the movie. Elizabeth Hurley is absolutely stunning in the movie, and she does manage to take on the role pretty well. The action scenes were done fine, but nothing spectacular about it. You do get some nice cameos like Will Ferrell, Tom Arnold, and such. The movie does hold up really well, but the jokes and the CG effects of the Big Boy could have been better. I still enjoy this movie and I am giving it a 9 out of 10.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: The premise of this film is solid - spoof 007 for all it's male narcissism, male sexual promiscuity, and stupid cliches. I thought the idea potentially fun, and Mike Myers was a guy to lead it.Overall, the fact that this movie isn't a dud and failure is itself a success. Normally, when a film's lead actor is also the primary (or sole) writer then you often have a (somewhat) myopic story. Sadly, that seems to be the case here.In the pursuit of avoiding many of the diseases that 007 and spy films (in general) have, this film cranks out the same drone. It's not that there aren't clever and funny moments , but the film constantly pauses and becomes wrapped up in itself (or Myers). This reminds a bit of Eddie Murphy's "The Nutty Professor" with so much emphasis on his comedic skill that the film can't breathe.STORY: Again, the story has potential, but gets mired in Myers' (or director's) handling of spoofs - he gets wrapped up in his own skits. If he'd removed himself from more, he'd have a better story, but as is, it's like he's doing a cultural diatribe. Frankly, Peter Sellers does a magnificently better job in the "Pink Panther" series from the 1960's and 1970's,ACTING: As expected, the acting is very good. Robert Wagner was a poor choice for "#2" as he appears almost disinterested in his role (or he had trouble not laughing).Though Myers is gifted, no one stands out.TEMPO: Start, stop, start, stop ... the whole way through.CINEMATOGRAPHY: This is the best part of the film (aside from some of Myers' antics), with lots of color, music, and ideas that flash and spark.DIRECTING: This was only the director's 2nd film (1st bombed) but went on to direct the "Meet the Parents" series, and later focused on made-for-TV drivel. Overall he did a good job here, but obviously he's more comfortable in a more controlled environment like TV.Summary: The film is very well acted, has some funny spoofing, and is pretty to watch. Unfortunately, it weighs on itself, and becomes constipated with self-obsession.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Even if this review has come off as slightly negative I would say this is a great watch and will keep you invested the whole way through.

Review title: One of the funniest films in decades
Review_body: I am somewhat late...not like Frau Farbissina...but late getting around to the Austin Powers films. Oh well...better late than never. I find myself not only on the floor laughing at these bad jokes done well ( and bad jokes sometimes done not so well) that I must confess I have become a Mike Myers fan as a result. Reality and sensibility are totally suspended, and it becomes pure entertainment and real fun. I will not generally go in for bad language or obscenity....but what there is of these in the Austin Powers films is done in such a deliberately comedic way that I find it easy to force myself to overlook it in most instances. One thing that is not forced is these films is the humor. The situations and the characters are truly funny, and I have found myself viewing this film repeatedly. Culturally literate baby-boomers who were around in these days will get a big kick out of it. I do not recommend this for children---but they probably will watch it anyway--just hope there's some adult supervision there to explain to them what was happening, and to help them along with the terminology and the groups of the era. Austin Powers is an absolute riot.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery
