Review_body: From the opening scene to the hilariously over the top finale, this is Mike Myers at the top of his game. This is more than just a clever pastiche of the James Bond franchise (and a host of other films), but a standalone piece of comedy genius. Every scene is perfectly crafted but in a way that seems effortless. And the cast are clearly having a whale of a time.The cuts away from the main narrative to the otherwise unfeatured family and friends of the henchmen that die along the way are inspired - and has become an often-imitated device in comedy (e.g. South Park).The dialogue is unforgettable and hilarious throughout, but the biggest coup the film pulls off is that it can be watched over and over again and the jokes don't get tired. I watched it six times at the cinema, introducing a host of friends to the film's charms - it is the only movie that has ever had that effect on me.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: What do you get when you cross Benny Hill with Monty Python? Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery.This movie is a goof on those lame James Bond spy movies. The evil Dr. Evil has come up with a master minded plan and has taken the world hostage! Who better to stop Dr. Evil then his rival Austin Powers. Trained by the British Spy Infantry, Austin looks to set off to find Dr. Evil. After finding him in a 70s swingers club, Dr. Evil escapes with his cat Mr. Bigglesworth. He cryogenically freezes himself in a Big Boy shaped space rocket. Austin has no other choice to be frozen himself.Dr. Evil makes his return to Earth in the 90's. His evil henchmen are all still loyal and there are some new faces. After the British Government hears of this, Austin is also brought out of his frozen coma. Problem for Austin, its not the 70's. No more swinging or promiscuous sex with other partners. He also seems to have a thing for his partner in crime, Ms. Kenzington. Dr. Evil thought up of a new evil plan and once again holds the world hostage. Our only hope is Austin Powers.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: Good First Movie in Austin Powers Trilogy
Review_body: For a starting movie in the Austin Powers Trilogy, I would have to say that this was pretty funny. It had a good cast. The actors and actresses seemed a little bit up-tight about their roles, but eventually they get more comfortable in the sequels "The Spy Who Shagged Me" & "Goldmember."The plot is basically that back in 1967, Dr. Evil, who threatened the world, froze himself and the only person that was able to defeat him, Austin Powers, froze himself as well. Dr. Evil defrosted himself in 1997 and Austin was then defrosted too. Dr. Evil's latest plan is to steal a nuclear warhead and hold the world hostage for one million dollars...which was later changed to one hundred billion dollars. Austin, with the help of his new partner Vanessa, adapts to the '90s and together they eventually defeat Dr. Evil.There were many great laughs. The characters were creative like Alotta Fagina. I was cracking up the whole time that she was on screen or if Austin and Vanessa referred to her in some way. "She's the village bicycle. Everyone's had a ride."Great perfomances by Robert Wagner as Number Two, Mindy Sterling as Frau, and Elizabeth Hurley as Vanessa Kensington really made the movie. Mike Myers plays Austin Powers and Dr. Evil really well. This movie was very well done. I would recommend anyone that is a spy movie fan or just someone looking for a good laugh to rent this movie. I highly recommend seeing the sequels if you like this and even if you don't like this, I would still recommend renting the sequels because the sequels seem to get better as the series goes on.I gave this movie a rating of 7 out of 10.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review_body: Austin Powers has the rare distinction of being a spoof film that is also original. Mike Myers stars as Groovy British spy Austin Powers. Who is cryogenically frozen in 1969 to do battle with the evil Blofeld Lookalike Dr.Evil (Also Myers). Austin is thawed out in 1997 to a very different world where Swingers are all but extinct. He is partnered up with the daughter of his original partner Vanessa Kensington (Elizabeth Hurley) to do battle with Dr.Evil and his hilarious Minions like Number 2 (Robert Wagner) and Frau Farbissina.Perfect film for James Bond fans; packed with lots of references to James Bond and the Spy Genre whilst also being able to be original. It has lots of quotable quotes like "Groovy". It also features parodies of Iconic James Bond scenes and great 60's costumes and locations. Great film and would highly recommend it- 10/10
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Austin Powers has always been a childhood favorite of mine, even though I should not have been watching it.
I think Austin Powers is hilarious and it's a super fun spoof of the James Bond films, but International Man of Mystery surprisingly hasn't aged well at all. I was quite saddened at just how sophomoric and juvenile this movie is. Did the movie make me laugh? Yeah. Often? Ehh, sadly no. I don't know if I can pin point why, but this movie is awkward and if feels it length instead of going by fast. One of the problems I can point out is that all the sex/sexual scenes aren't funny at all, so there's this weird blurred line between trying to be funny and trying to make you aroused so you just look at it in confusion. The 2 latter Austin Powers films are really funny because they are just so outragous but this one struggles to get off the ground. The pee gag that lasts almost a whole minute still cracks me up but there are some pretty lame jokes that go on for too long like the evil laugh scene. There is some pretty good 007 parody stuff in the movie but some of it was WAY too on the nose, i.e when Dr. Evil deliberately admits that his trap is easy to escape. I enjoy the nuance and the subtly of the spoof aspects but at some points they just tossed it in the garbage.The Spy Who Shagged Me and Goldmember are hilarious and I would like to see a 4th one but I think I'll be skipping this one from now on.

Review_body: Most of the comments seem to cast this as a lowbrow vs highbrow humor issue. I like lowbrow humor as much as anyone--give me Benny Hill and toilet humor any day--but this movie is just badly done. The script needs a script doctor to tighten it up and the direction, editing, and pacing is way off key. The biggest problem is that they don't know when to stop and they let gags that are potentially funny just die by dragging them out. Austin says, "I like women of that calibre" after the go-go girls uses her bra gun ... but then he has to go on to explain the pun ... and then there's a long pause and a long giggle--by the time all this is over the joke has been completely killed. Austin announces his ransom demand to the UN, and then gives a parody of the evil villian's laugh--funny--and he laughs again--funny. By the time the punchline comes (everyone's laugh petering out) it's the 20th repitition, and the viewer doesn't care anymore. There was lots of potential here, but it was squandered. All the good parts are in the trailer--watch that and buy an Austin Powers promotional penis enlarger, but skip the movie.

Review_body: This film has gained wide popular appeal, leading some to dismiss it as a lowbrow, sophomoric attempt; to be lumped in with Sandler and his ilk. But this is not the case.While Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery does contain it's fair share of (genuinely funny) sight gags and rude humour, it also succeeds comedically on a much higher level. The precision with which Myers simultaneously both satirizes and pays homage to the spy films of the sixties (including, but not limited to, the classic Bonds) and '60s swinger culture is uncanny. In both Dr. Evil and Austin, Myers creates rich, highly memorable characters whose personalities give rise to the film's humour; as opposed to the flat, one-dimensional characters that comedies are so often saddled with. As a screenwriter, Myers is both highly literate and well-read. His dialogue (both in its writing and its delivery) is classic: well-scripted, well-phrased and well-timed. While Myers undeniably carries the film, the supporting cast is also terrific. Elizabeth Hurley, Michael York and Robert Wagner all successfully bring their respective characters to life, and sparkle in their relationships with Austin and Dr. Evil, respectively.The pacing and direction are top-notch. Never does a scene drag on to the point of annoying the viewer, and the plot barely gives you time to catch your breath. The cinematography is above-average for a comedy; the special effects are a terrific mix of competent modern technology and perfectly understated vintage sixties film techniques (rear-projection, pasted-on gun flashes, etc.). The sets and costumes, similarly, are self-consciously true to the genre ("Do you like your quasi-futuristic clothes, Mr. Powers? I designed them myself."), which only adds to the movie's humour.All in all, this is a brilliant film, mixing in exactly the right proportions belly-laugh gags with a genuinely sly, subtle level of satire. Highly recommended.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Review title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery
Review_body: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery is a comedy/science fiction film by definition. This is the first installment of the Austin Powers series. Austin Powers was premiered in 1997. Directed by Jay Roach and written by Mike Myers, who stars a dual role in the film. The Austin Powers films were intended be a parody off of the James Bond movies. The film starts out in 1967, with Austin Powers a British spy who attempts to assassinate his nemesis Dr. Evil. Dr. Evil successfully escapes, launching himself in a space rocket disguised as a Big Boy's statue. From there the movie jumps forward, 30 years in time to 1997. The film stars Mike Myers as Austin Powers and Dr. Evil, Elizabeth Hurley as Vanessa Kensington, and Will Ferrell as Mustafa among other talented actors and actresses. The theme of the film parodies numerous James Bond, Derek Flint, Jason King, and Matt Helm films, characters, and video games. These films are incorporated with other elements of pop culture and they follow the British spy's heroic quest to bring the villain Doctor Evil to justice. The films poke fun at the outrageous plots, rampant sexual innuendo, and one-dimensional stock characters associated with 1960s spy films, as well as the cliché of the ultra-suave male super spy. Contrary to the handsome, super-smooth leading men of the James Bond genre, Austin Powers is not characterized as being conventionally attractive (he is especially known for his bad teeth), although female characters in the films seem to find him irresistible. The general theme of the films is that the arch-villain Dr. Evil plots to extort large sums of money from governments or international bodies but is constantly thrown off by British super-spy Austin Powers, and (to a degree) his own inexperience with life and culture in the 1990s.There's a lot of lighting effects that are used in the film. All the explosions and fire are effects that are used to enhance the film. For example, when Dr. Evil is escaping from Austin in his "space ship" disguised as the Big Boy statue, it appears as if he is traveling through space, all lighting effects. The angels that are used in the film are pretty much a standard, straight on, clear cut shot. The director uses some close ups to enhance the features of The Man of Mystery, for example his teeth. These techniques are two of the most important in my opinion, when it comes to a film we all want to be entertained. It's funny how a simple flashing light or a camera angle can affect how we watch a film and how much we enjoy the actual film.
Movie_name: Austin Powers - International Man of Mystery

Watch the second movie "Austin Powers, the Spy who Shagged Me" once you have seen this one - and not before. This is what great comedians do. They take what they know & love and point out the laughs that can be had from it. Ironically, I just saw an interview with Mike Myers in which he admitted that his family, particularly his mother, were of the opinion - and may still be - that Mike was/is not funny. His mother, a Liverpool, England native, has always told him, "your brothers are funny - but not you Michael" ??? BRAVO, Mr Myers, you proved mum wrong. We just have to sit back and enjoy. THUMBS UP.
